hook.text: You consume more information in one day than a medieval person did in a lifetime. Your brain wasn't built for this.

buildup.text: Information overload impairs decision-making. Too many inputs paralyze the brain's ability to prioritize.

discovery.text: Herbert Simon predicted it: 'A wealth of information creates a poverty of attention.' He said that in 1971.

twist.text: More information doesn't make you smarter. It makes you anxious. Curated input beats unlimited input every time.

climax.text: Limit your information diet: three trusted sources, scheduled check-ins, and deliberate ignorance of the rest.

punchline.text: Less information, better decisions. Curate ruthlessly.

quiz.question: What did Herbert Simon predict about information abundance?
options: A wealth of information creates a poverty of attention
